message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF with a stable GFR suggests a decreased efferent arteriole constriction. Among the options, only drugs that constrict the efferent arteriole, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), can lead to this result.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF and FF suggests that the drug she was started on has a vasoconstrictive effect on the efferent arterioles, thereby decreasing blood flow in the glomerulus and increasing filtration fraction. Among the options, only drugs that constrict efferent arterioles will increase filtration fraction, and ACE inhibitors and AT1 receptor blockers are the most commonly used medications for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF and increase in FF suggests constriction of the efferent arteriole. Drugs that can cause this include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). NSAIDs are known to decrease renal blood flow and GFR without affecting RPF, leading to an increase in FF.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The change in RPF and FF suggests that the patient was started on a drug that constricts the efferent arteriole, which would increase FF and decrease RPF. Options (A) and (B) would increase GFR and RPF. Option (C) would decrease RPF and GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF and FF indicates constriction of the efferent arteriole. Among the options, only drugs that constrict the efferent arteriole would decrease RPF and increase FF.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF and increase in FF suggest a constriction of the efferent arteriole. Among the options, drugs that constrict the efferent arteriole include ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs), which can be used to treat hypertension and reduce proteinuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF and constant filtration rate suggests constriction of the efferent arteriole. Among the options, only drugs that constrict the efferent arteriole can increase filtration fraction without decreasing GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this question, we need to identify the drug that caused a decrease in RPF and an increase in FF. Among the options, only constriction of the efferent arteriole will cause this effect, and drugs that can cause this include ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers. Therefore, the patient was most likely started on one of these medications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The change in RPF and FF suggests that the patient is on an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB). These drugs constrict the efferent arteriole and decrease the glomerular filtration rate. Inhibition of the renal Na-K-Cl cotransporter or vasopressin would affect water and salt reabsorption, but not directly affect RPF or FF. Constriction of the afferent arteriole would decrease both RPF and GFR, but FF would not be affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in RPF and constant GFR suggest constriction of the efferent arteriole. This is typically seen with drugs such as ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers, which are commonly used to treat hypertension and can also have beneficial effects on kidney function.
